posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked:
My robot’s arm has 2 falcons controlling it, and a cancoder that is 1 to 1 with the rotation of the arm. When I try to use

The arm’s movement becomes very jerky as if it is starting and stopping over and over again.

This happens both when I use Motion Magic

and when I use control mode percent output

Motion Magic and Percent Output both work when I just use the leader motor and set the other one to coast mode.

Full Code

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked:
This is interesting… Have you plotted the motor’s output in phoenix tuner? I would be curious to know what going on in the motor.

It could be that having that extra motor on there is more power than your control loop is expecting. Do you get that behavior if you make the d gain 0?

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: The I and D values are both 0. When looking at the lights on the motors, the leader one is solid green while it is moving while the follower motor flashes green and orange.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked:
This is the leader motor image 1384×464 8.44 KB

image 1384×464 8.44 KB

image 1384×464 8.44 KB

The follower motor had no motor output (the line was 0 the whole time)

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: the LEDs changing on the follower makes me think it’s losing its setpoint… Can you plot the % output of the follower? I wonder if there is a wiring snafu, or maybe you’re commanding the motor to 0 somewhere else in the code.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked:
That graph was when I tried manually controlling it (by setting the percentage output). The same jerky problem happened and when I looked at the motor ouput follower graph, it was all 0. image 1251×445 8 KB

image 1251×445 8 KB

image 1251×445 8 KB

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: When I set the follower motor to Coast mode, the jerkiness goes away. This suggests that the follower motor is being set to a speed of 0. Why?

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: That’s a good question. It could be code or it could be a wiring issue… I would look through your code and check every reference to that motor controller to make sure there isn’t a motor.set that you forgot about. Self test your follow motor and see if their are any sticky faults, or if anything looks strange in general. Probably unrelated but you don’t have to invoke motor.follow every time you command your leader. Do it once in init unless you command those motors independently at some other point, but I don’t think you do.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked:
I got it working by changing the config stuff to

I’m not exactly sure how this fixed it. Do you know how I can add configRemoteFeedbackFilter and configSelectedFeedbackSensor to the config rather than using the methods to do it?

There is, but i have found that to be a bad life choice (did what you saw earlier). Honestly i would stick to periodically synchronizing them (set the integrated encoder position/configSelectedSensorPosition) that way you can take full advantage of the closed-loop PID in the TalonFX

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: can you tell me what you changed specifically?

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: I changed it to creating the talon config object rather than configuring each setting through the config methods

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: Thats real weird than idk. Either you’ve stumbled on a real weird edge case, or maybe it was a wiring issue that resolved itself? Either way I’m happy everything is working.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: Yeah lol I’m not sure, thanks for all the support!

I’ll just make a comment, don’t know if this is what was causing the problem. I haven’t worked with Falcons, but looking at the API it looks to be similar to REV. I believe you only need to set the follow in the constructor and the constant calls to for the motor to follow could be causing some sort of lock up in the TalonFX controller.

I’ve experienced problematic calls of constantly setting brake or coast mode, so I don’t know if the constantly calling follow could be causing it or not.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: I tried doing it both ways before I made the post, and the issue was still happening. I still have no idea what was causing the problem.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked:
We figured out what the problem was:

I will no longer be messing with can.
